text:
Why must you take great
care when emerging from
this junction?
explanation: The view is restricted. Restricted visibility at junctions means you must emerge very carefully as hazards may be hidden.

text:
Which type of vehicle
should you be ready to give
way to as you approach this
bridge?
explanation: Buses. Buses are wide vehicles that may need to use the center of the road on narrow bridges.

text:
What type of vehicle
could you expect to meet in
the middle of the road?
explanation: Lorry. Large lorries often need to move to the middle of narrow roads to navigate safely.

text:
What should you do if the red lights start flashing as you approach a level 
crossing?

options.D: Switch on your hazard warning lights

explanation: Pedestrians may step out in front of you. Bus stops mean pedestrians who may cross without looking.

text:
How should you drive or
ride in areas with traffic-
calming measures?

options.C: In the centre of the road

explanation: At a reduced speed. Traffic calming measures are designed to slow traffic down - drive slowly and carefully.

text:
What type of vehicle uses an amber flashing beacon on a dual 
carriageway?
explanation: A tractor. Tractors and other slow-moving vehicles use amber flashing beacons to warn other traffic.

text:
What does this signal
from a police officer mean to
oncoming traffic?
explanation: Stop. This police signal means traffic must stop - the officer's palm facing you means stop.

text:
Where would it be unsafe
to overtake?
explanation: Approaching a junction. Never overtake near junctions - vehicles may turn or emerge suddenly.

text:
What does the solid
white line at the side of the
road indicate?
explanation: Edge of the carriageway. Solid white lines mark the edge of the road.

text:
You're driving towards this level crossing. What 
would be the first warning of an approaching train?
explanation: A steady amber light. The amber light comes on first as an initial warning that a train is approaching.

text:
What will become more expensive after you've been convicted of driving while unfit through drink or 
drugs?
explanation: Insurance premiums. Drink/drug driving convictions significantly increase insurance costs.

text:
You're driving on a one-
way street. What should you
do if you realise you've
taken the wrong route?

options.B: Turn around in a side road

explanation: Continue and find another route. Never reverse on a one-way street - continue and find another way.

text:
You've been involved in an argument that's made 
you feel angry. What should you do before starting your journey?
explanation: Calm down. Never drive when angry or emotional - wait until you've calmed down.

text:
You've just been 
overtaken by this 
motorcyclist. What should you do if the rider cuts in sharply?
explanation: Keep a safe gap. Maintain a safe following distance even if someone cuts in front of you.

text:
How does drinking
alcohol affect your driving
behaviour?
explanation: It increases confidence. Alcohol gives false confidence while actually impairing driving ability.

text: Which type of glasses would make driving at night more difficult?
explanation: Tinted. Tinted glasses reduce light transmission, making night driving more difficult.

text:
You're driving a car fitted with automatic 
transmission. When would you use ‘kick-down’?
explanation: To accelerate quickly. Kick-down in automatic transmission provides maximum acceleration when needed.

text:
You're driving towards this left-hand bend. What danger should you be 
anticipating?
explanation: Pedestrians walking towards you. On left-hand bends, pedestrians on your side face away so may not see you.
